content: I modified test 2 to conform to the standards set by validator 2 and the problem statement
This contribution hasn‚Äôt received enough positive votes from the community. The "REVERSE" option has therefore been deactivated.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
I'm conflicted as to admittance of reverse. Is it gonna be too hard?
I think it's better to have analogous tests and validators? Like... have an error validator paired an error test and same for valid ones.
Created the python code don't hesitate to give me feedbacks.
Shouldn't test case nr 5 and the validator be true? or as you mentioned the rotated sentence.

Someone changed the code (in python3) to :
sentence = input().split()

arr=[(len(v),i) for i,v in enumerate(sentence)]
arr.sort(key=lambda x : x[0])
for i in range(len(arr)-1):
    if arr[i][0]+1!=arr[i+1][0]:
        print("ERROR")
        exit(0)
print(' '.join([sentence[a[1]] for a in arr]))

But it can't pass test 5 (added after ankursatle remark) so I put back my longer (and correct) javascript code

What I understand you were doing in this python3 code was reordering the words of the sentence (the sort) without constraint to check if you can make an increasing one. But by rotating the words (the constraint) you can't create any sentence you like, that's why test5 doesn't pass.

I have updated the example in the statement (" Example with the sentence "The grey Mo" and its two only possible rotated forms ") to try to make the CoC clearer.

I would like to suggest a test-case too: 
Input: 
333 4444 55555 666666 22 7777777

Output:
ERROR

The idea is to have a sentence with words with length diff of 1 but jumbled up in order so that it is not possible to only rotate and form a 'valid' sentence. This is trying to check if the programmer has incorrectly 're-ordered' the words instead of only rotating them.

I suggest Output be rephrased from its existing: 
Line1 :The rotated sentence if the sentence is valid , else ERROR
to 
Line1 :The rotated <b>valid<b> sentence if one exists, else ERROR

Thanks, good puzzle.
cool
Really interesting one.

I'm here to say that I like this puzzle and enjoy solving it! I hope this one pass to be in the main game. But because English isn't my mother language, I can't comment about the words/sentences used in the statement. But by the way, Upvoted.

Interesting puzzle.  I'd just suggest to review the wording, since "sentence is good" suggests some judgement on the text, which sounds somewhat confusing.  What about "You have to determine if a sentence is right increasing sentence.  A right increasing sentence is .... "  or "You have to check if the words .... " or any other formulation that avoids good or bad.

If  you downvote, please say why !
Thanks
What do you think of a "valid sentence"?  A sentence is valid if by successively rotating...

If other people think like ankusatle please upvote him.
Right now I ll just put valid in bold, I don't know if his way is more english or clearer than mine !
Why not, I could add "quick to the vast plains".

No, "quick to the vast plains" gives at best after 4 rotation to the right "to the vast plains quick" and this is a sequence of words of size 2,3,4,6,5 and it's not increasing (it should have been 2,3,4,5,6).

How dare you ! A shorter version than my javascript code, on my Coc !

Well done :)
Done.

I think it will be too hard. The code is not easy to write when you have the explanation, perhaps an average of 10 mn to make it work, if you add the time to understand the logic (it doesn't seem difficult but we have the explanation :) ), I think it will be too short for a lot of players.
I prefer average difficulty or "easy" CoC. Difficulty can be found in puzzles or other contests.
Fair enough.
if you decide to add the "reverse" mode, I'd suggest adding a test with words of size 1, 2 and 3 and maybe another with long words but not many.
So, under pressure :) ,  I have added a few more tests (6,7,8) and activated the reverse mode !

We can really shorten this code.
My only goal was to provide a code that could be easily understood :)

Let's just say that python code is more fitted about these problematics than Javascript :)

Amazing. I think I wrote little code in haskell that made it pass the 4 tests with validators. I organised the words by their length, ant then checked. I think if you add one more test like test 5 would be great to prevent cheating. üëç

That new example is very useful (again tx to ankursatle).
I don't understand why adding a new test like the 5 will be useful, the 5 already prevents the possible sort by word length "cheat".
But if your argument is valid I will add one of course !

Yeah. if you want use this Haskell code to see if it's valid. I've tested it more than one time. Just copy paste all over. ^^

import System.IO
import Control.Monad
import Data.Ord
import Data.List

main :: IO ()
main = do
    hSetBuffering stdout NoBuffering -- DO NOT REMOVE
    
    -- Auto-generated code below aims at helping you parse
    -- the standard input according to the problem statement.
    
    sentence <- getLine
    let x = unwords $ sortBy (comparing length) (words sentence)
    let b = map length $ sortBy (comparing length) (words sentence)
    if [(head b).. (last b)] == b then putStrLn x else  putStrLn "ERROR"

I meant I already added test 5 and its validator with the same pattern, your code (the cheat :) ) can't pass it so all is ok.
But I thought you asked for a 6th test with the same pattern as the 5th ("I think if you add one more test like test 5 would be great to prevent cheating") ... and so I didn't understand why !
Haha, yeah sorry mate I meant 6th test case. My bad. Yeah and awesome that the cheat code didn‚Äôt pass. üòÉ

Good idea ! a "valid sentence that fulfils the following constraint:  ...".   By the way, I tested your puzzle (c++) and it was fun.  It took me unfortunately too much time to fit in the 12 minutes of a clash of code. I'd therefore suggest to give guarantees that no punctuation will occur and that spacing between words will always be simple space.

So I will change to valid.
I have also doubts about its difficulty, it's a bit hard to finish it in 15mn. it's easier if you already have the rotate function code somewhere.
I don't see how anyone would have trouble in 15 minutes, even 10. I am pretty slow at these usually and it took me 4 minutes.

How about renaming the term 'valid' to 'ascending'. 
e.g. An Ascending Sentence
or A sentence is 'ascending' if...
or It's an ascending sentence because...

It will help the programmers not have to hunt for the meaning of 'valid'. 'Ascending' should mean roughly the same to everyone as against 'valid' which needs to be understood more.

What do you think?

I propose to change the beginning ,
"You have to test if a sentence complies with our rule.

Our rule : a sentence is valid if by successively ..."
to:
"You have to test if a sentence is valid.

A sentence is valid if by successively ..."
